content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The only thing I would add is a reference to part one.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: great
Very nice

Nice follow up to part one. :)

Goal
error case:
I was a bit confused when I read "does not comply with the statement" as there was no mention that the message to be encoded must be only uppercase letters and spaces. My understanding at that point was that we could decode all printable ascii characters from the key and not just uppercase letters. And the example just says "BO0OO is wrong" without mentioning what part is wrong. I propose to change it to:

For an {{Encode}}, if the message does not contain only uppercase letters and spaces, you must write {{ERROR !!}}.
For a {{DECODE}}, if the message does not contain only hexadecimal digits and {{G}}s, you must write {{ERROR !!}}.

Cheers.

Goal
* Please change:

Hexadecimal conversion: A = 6 => Hex: 6, B = 15 => Hex: F, C = 21 => Hex: 15

Values are separated by "G", and spaces by "GG". An EC option indicates "ENCODE" or "DECODE."

to:

The resulting integers are then converted to hexadecimal in uppercase, separated by {{G}}, e.g. {{ABC}} is transformed into {{6, 15, 21}}, which is then converted to {{6GFG15}}.

(Notes:
1. There aren't any cases which require {{GG}} yet, so I've omitted that for now.
2. I don't think it's necessary to mention [[EC]] here.)

Input
* Please rewrite the whole section using this format:

<<Line _>>: variable_type [[variable_name]] variable_description

Follow the example here: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement#guidelines

Remember to use the same variable names as the stub generator (except that "key" would be changed to "n" to be consistent with Goal section. Or you may change "n" to "key" in Goal section instead.)

Output
* Please rewrite the whole section:
<<1 line>>: The decoded/encoded message

(Note: There is no error case, so I've omitted that for now.)

Constraints
* Please format "n" as a [[variable]].

* Please change the upper bound of n to 50000 or 10‚Åµ to reflect better the actual cases.

* There aren't any spaces in the messages right now.

Cases
* It is weird that only one test is being named (Test 3: BIG KEY).

* Suggest to add two more pairs of cases of ENCODE (i.e. 2 tests and 2 validators).

Thanks.

Thank you for your help. I hope it is better now
At the moment, my project is a "work in progress."
At 5 AM, I was too tired to continue; I'm sure you know the feeling üòâ
Regarding the use cases, I will add more, for sure.
For example, "GGG" could represent an error (there are many cases like this), or a limit case like "GG" for the ending character.

Oh, one question: how can I test the execution time to create a timeout test and ensure the code is optimized?

Hey,
Thanks for your feedback! I‚Äôve taken it into account and reworked the statement. I clarified the encoding/decoding rules, added examples, and specified the error cases. I think everything is good now! If you like this part, the third part will be even more exciting, trust me üòâ. Feel free to let me know if you have any feedback or adjustments.
thank you
thx
good idea ! can I write a link ?
The "link" will be shown as text only, not a link you can click on.

Now that the section "Input format" has been added, I feel "Error case" can be reduced to:

<<Error case:>>  (notice E is capitalized)
If [[message]] does not comply with its respective input format, you must return {{ERROR !!}}.

As input format is now very explicit, error case is a bit redundant imo. If you want to keep it as is (which is fine, I am nitpicking here) you can add a space after the colon in "B0GO0G00": The message.

Sign me up for third part then :p

You're right, the simpler, the better.
I've finished the third part, but I need this second part done first.

thank you for your help
When I wrote "Error case: (notice E is capitalized)", I mentioned E was capitalized because you forgot to capitalize it, you can remove the part between parenthesis from the statement. :D
Get notified :D it seems you didn't see my message

I had some "F..." issues with my internet connection, but it's done now. 
Thanks for your contribution.

What's your opinion on new part of my puzzle?
a third part will come?

Wow! Thank you so much for these very detailed explanations and corrections. Sorry for some language subtleties, English is not my native language.
As for the next part, in Part 3: spoiler, you'll have to break the encryption and decrypt without the key.

No worries!

The idea for Part 3 sounds interesting.

Not sure whether you've finished updating the puzzle yet? Here are the outstanding points as at this moment:

Goal
* In the example:

  ‚Ä¢ Please change [[n]] to [[key]].
  
  ‚Ä¢ Please change "could" to "will" (twice).

* Please explain what error cases the player should handle.

Input
* Please change "operator" to "operation" so that it is the same as the name used in the stub generator.

* Please format "operation" as a [[variable]].

* Please change "[[ENCODE]]" and "[[DECODE]]" to "{{ENCODE}}" and "{{DECODE}}".

Output
* Please change to:
<<1 line>>: The decoded or encoded message, or {{ERROR !!}}

Constraints
* Please change "letters" to "upper case letters", and remove the last constraint.

* Please format "message" as a [[variable]].

Tags
* Have you used "Dynamic programming" in your solution code? If not, how is it relevant to this puzzle?

Cases
* There are Tests 10/12 and Validators 10/12, but Test 11 and Validator 11 are missing.

* There are 8 pairs of "DECODE" cases, but only 3 pairs of "ENCODE" cases. Please add more "ENCODE" cases.

Thanks.

Thank you so much.
I will add 3 encode test it wil be enough ?

for the part 3  will  be finish soon, but it was hard...

You're welcome üôÇ

3 pairs should be ok, though 5 pairs will be better. But it's up to you.

Take your time to finish part 3! We don't want part 3 to be approved earlier than part 2 anyway üòâ

Goal
* Please change "A could be" to "A =" in the example.

Tags
* Have you used "Dynamic programming" in your solution code? If not, how is it relevant to this puzzle? Should you remove the tag?

Thanks.

Thank you, I hope it is ok now.
For part 3, I will be much more precise, and I will adhere better to the statement's 
 guidelines.

Comments after your latest update:

Goal
* Please change "<<ENCODE>>" to "For an {{ENCODE}} [[operation]], [[message]]".

* Please change "<<DECODE>>" to "For a {{DECODE}} [[operation]], [[message]]".

* Please change "upper case" to "uppercase" for consistency (or the other way round).

* Please delete "(notice E is capitalized)".

Output / Constraints
* Please change "upper case" to "uppercase" for consistency (or if you prefer "upper case", no change is required here).

Thanks.

Done.
But you're a real human compiler lol!! 
Thank you for your always insightful remarks.

Thank you for your praise! üòÜ

There may be some misunderstanding. Please change as follows (under the heading of "Input format"):

For an {{ENCODE}} [[operation]], [[message]] contains only upper case letters and spaces.
For a {{DECODE}} [[operation]], [[message]] contains only upper case hexadecimal values and the upper case letter {{G}}.

Hope this clarifies. Thanks again.
done, I hope my contribution will be approve
Sometimes a contribution can get approved very quickly just before the 30-day period is up, but sometimes it can also take several months for a contribution to get approved, so, be patient! üòâ
I will be, I promise.But I'm so excited to release part 3 because it's the one I made the first two parts for.
